comments.commentBody:
Honestly, Jews and Muslims have more in common in this regard than any other. When a Muslim goes on a murdering rampage, Muslims everywhere get blamed for it. When Israel's policies toward Palestine seem unfair, all Jews get blamed for it. Both groups have to do more to protect themselves from guilt by association. It's basic human nature.

It's not so much anti-Semitic as it is ignorant.

The fact that all Jewish students are "perceived" to be pro-Israel (whatever that is) and punished for the plight of the Palestinians is indeed anti-semitic. Are Chinese students held accountable for the policies of Beijing?
Be serious:  this is clearly the result of pro-Palestinian students challenging someone they perceive to be pro-Israel.  It is not anti-semitism.
So, you think this line of questioning for the Jewess student was appropriate?

So, from now on we should demand every applicant to turn over records of every organization and Political Action Committee that they and, more importantly, their parents have donated funds to in the past 5 years.

The fact that seems absurd sheds light on the problems with this claim. Further, what does Netanyahu's behavior (invited by the party that controls our national legislature, I might add) have to do with this candidate? Somehow Young US Jews have to take responsibility for what people halfway around the world are doing? So, likewise, I expect young US Catholics to be responsible for the actions of the Pope, not to mention various other nations with professed Catholic ties, young US people of Japanese descent for their immigration policies, and young US Muslims for the endemic violence that convulses the Middle East just b/c some of the states there profess to speak for their faith.
I can't even the change the practices of the US state. And I'm a citizen!

Excuse me. Republicans support Israel. The US congress supports Israel. How would that support affect qualification for this job. I did not hear any mention of Israel by the students only in these comments. What does this judicial board judge? Do they deal with Israel or student misconduct? How can these clearly biased students question the bias of others.

This is a "learning moment" for all of us - I can not accept that the students who asked uncomfortable questions are stupid and anti-Sematic. The current generation of kids attending the primer education institutions are seeing the world with their glasses and the historic sympathies for Jews sufferings are not coloring these glasses. What they see - a state based on Jews history and unconditionally supported by global Jews community, is practicing occupation and Apethied with blatant support from US Jews organizations. Even their political leader have the udacity to insult our President. This is the context. You can not color this by crying anti-sematism. Be realistic and see what is happening in the world. Young US Jews have to take the responsibility and change their community and practices of Jews state -  listen to another Jew from MIT.

Split loyalties? I was born and raised in America. I am proud to be an American and grateful for the freedoms and opportunities I enjoy here as a citizen. I am also a Jew who supports Israel. Like countless other Americans of various ethnic backgrounds (whose loyalty is NOT similarly challenged), I hold dear to my heart another homeland. It is where my grand- and great-grandparents were born; my ancestors laid to rest on the Mt of Olives in the mid-1800s.

But my support is not simply sentimental: Israel is the sole democracy in the region and refuge for various indigenous minorities of the Middle East. Israel has my support as an American who believes in equal rights for women, gay marriage, freedom of religion, and the right to self-determination for historically persecuted and endangered ethnic groups.

Organizations and individuals who "find sympathy with the Palestinian cause" do not represent the entire student body, or champion universally agreed-upon values or the political beliefs of the average American. They have a right to operate on campus, but why should they be exempt from criticism by student representatives? The suggestion that Jewish ethnic/religious/cultural ties are uniquely and inherently incompatible with student government participation is shockingly UN-American, and plainly antisemitic.

CAG: '...Honestly, given how strident so many Jews in America are in their support of Israel...'

You lost me at 'strident'.

Only Jews are called out for what happens in a country far away. A country where they are not citizens. Why don't the commenters here call out every single ethnic and religious group in America for things that people in far away countries do?

Honestly, given how strident so many Jews in America are in their support of Israel, it seems rather disingenuous to cry foul when folks on campus who are outraged at what is happening in Israel would question a student who is active in Jewish organizations about whether her attitudes and opinions might influence her decision on campus are unaffected by her allegiance to her faith.  How will organizations and individuals who find sympathy with the Palestinian cause fair at the hands of this student?  These questions are relevant to sound decision making and deserve to be answered.  Honestly, the tendency of Jewish leaders to cry anti-Semitism whenever questions are raised about Israel or the behavior of Americans who do in fact have split loyalties between the country where they live and the country they so often champion, is downright silly.  I'm sorry that faculty members intervened in this situation.  I believe students unhappiness with how Israel is treating Palestinians should be encouraged, not ignored.
Really? I don't recall John Roberts being grilled about whether or not he could be unbiased because he is Christian.

Anti-Semitism predates the establishment of the State of Israel and hatred of Israel predates the "occupation" of "Palestine" since from 1948 - 1967 there were no occupied territories and no settlements. I advise you to revisit the historical record and see for yourself that in 1947, a two-state solution was proposed in Mandated Palestine. The plan was accepted by the Jewish leadership and rejected by all Arab leaders. Had the Arabs not rejected the United National Partition Plan in 1947, there would have 2 states now.
Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington.

The articles says, "The four students who opposed her wrote a letter of apology ...[saying] 'Our intentions were never to attack, insult or delegitimize the identity of an individual or people.... [We] are truly sorry for any words used during this meeting that suggested otherwise.'" "Ms. Roth, in an email Thursday evening,... [wrote] 'I have already apologized profusely for what happened during our council meeting and I deeply regret how I phrased my questions to Rachel'."

What these quotes demonstrate is that these people still don't get it. Either that or what they regret is misjudging the reaction to their performance auditioning for a future as a member of Congress or a radio talk show host.
Yeah, those Jews just control everything, right cbreeze?

The association is definitely unfair, but it's also not fair to give Israel a pass on everything. For example, hitting a UN compound with a Geneva convention banned weapon deserves criticism whether the offender is Israel or any other group. You should not conflate criticism of Israeli policy with rants that Israel should not be allowed to exist. This is the same kind of thinking that leads people to blame Jews for the situation in the Middle East.

That's the purpose of the sorority.   It doesn't mean that she joins the Council with the intent of  imposing any sort of "experience" on others.   As someone pointed out above, students join many different clubs with different missions.  If the goal of the football team is to promote athletics and to win football games, does that mean that the athlete is precluded from serving in student government or that he will be forcing athletics and football playing down every student's throat?
Absolutely right, DH94114.  The solution is to get the Jews out of Israel.  How about moving them to San Francisco?  Do you have a spare bedroom you could contribute?
No, I think expulsion is quite right. These people should be cast out into society without the benefit of a UCLA diploma, whatever that's still worth after another incident like this.

So students are not allowed to make mistakes? Are they meant to arrive at college already understanding everything there is to know about cultural difference and effective governance? "Behavior like this" is unfortunate because it was hurtful but it was not despicable. To say so assumes that tolerance is something we come into this world with rather than something we have to learn--and teach. Let's give the students and administrators here some room to to both.

So, Edward, anti-semetism is not despicable? What needs to be uttered to get on your despicable list? Overt anti-semetism is not a "mistake". Their pitiful "apology" shows the only wrong they are owning up to is choice of wrong words.

Anti-Semitism is defined as hostility toward or discrimination against Jews as a religious, ethnic, or racial group. Ms. Beyda is the unfortunate recipient of hostility, for no other reason than her Jewishness. In other words, the UCLA Judicial Board exhibited anti-Semitism. All members that voted against Ms. Abeyta should be expelled from school immediately. Behavior like this cannot be tolerated.

Is Israel the only or main country responsible for world peace?
What has Israel to do with the Sunni/Shia/Kurd divide in the Middle East?
What has Israel to do with Putin's attempt to recreate the Soviet Union by invading fist Ukraine, and possibly other countries in the future?
What does Israel have to do with the Assad regime in Syria?
Answer: nothing, nothing and nothing.
There lies the problem.
Given the positions and actions of the religious right in this country, can we really blame such a question?
That's about as good a rationale for violence as I've read. I'm an American ex-pat. Bush et al are admitted war criminals. Should I expect to accept Anti-American bias on that account?
No it is not. Learn some history.

Given the current anti-Islamic and anti-immigration fervor I've seen (the former of which is from an etymological view also anti-Semitism), I am inclined to say that there's a good possibility we'd see it applied to a wide group.

@Carol Wheeler
Mr. Netanyahu is not my president, nor is he the president of other American Jews.
Why do you hide behind an alias?

So your saying the the Jewess Rachel Beyda was properly treated since Jews are so powerful? Does the term anti-semite ring a bell?

As far as Chinese people and China are concerned, the proper question to ask is why is China not facing boycotts despite it's decades-long repression of Tibet and the Uyghur people while the Jewish state of Israel is.

'... I would suggest that that is the basis for the issue here, not that the student is Jewish...'

Should a student with an opinion other than that of the 'correct thinking' espoused by most college professors regarding the Israel-Palestinian conflict automatically disqualify that person from holding office in a student organization then?
Does that make it okay? ie at UCLA it is okay to be pro-BDS but it is not okay to be pro-Israel?
No, you shouldn't assume. She is from Switzerland and not Jewish.

As a Jewish person with a clearly Jewish last name on a college campus in California I experience no prejudice. None at all. Nor have I heard of anyone else I know experiencing prejudice simply associated with being Jewish or having Jewish heritage.
The issue here might be associated with Hillel membership. Hillel, and Hillel members, in my experience, are 110 percent pro Israel with no apologies or nuance. I would suggest that that is the basis for the issue here, not that the student is Jewish.
I'm willing to bet a lot that a Muslim has been questioned in such a way at some university in this country.
We'd need to dig through all of their minutes to see if such a line of questioning happened but was simply not reported prominently in the NYT.
